description.narrative: Create a network for learning and sharing of protocols and processes to identify solutions, experiment and generate collective intelligence.

condition.narrative: UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 Number of new data sources used at Country Office level. 1.2 Diversity of different data sources used 1.3 Number of sustainable development solutions identified and documented 1.4 Variety of innovation methods used to test and iterate over the different hypotheses.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 Learning the Accelerator Lab Network shares with a public audience (outside of UNDP) 2.2 Number of lab insights, processes or products which are taken up by governments or other partners 2.3 Proportion of partners and governments that increase their take up of the innovation methods included in the Accelerator Lab Network suite 2.4 Proportion of UNDP Country Office programming influenced by the Accelerator Lab Network’s work and methodologies
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 Size and density of the network effects among the Accelerator Labs 3.2 Number of new models, approaches, and insights documented and disseminated throughout the network. 3.3 Engagement of the broader development ecosystem with published learnings from the Accelerator Lab Network. 3.4 Amount of influence the learnings and methods of the Accelerator Lab Networks have on the discourse of the broader development ecosystem.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 2 new sources of data per year 1.2 3 different type of data sources per year 1.3 20 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 2 innovation methods per Action Plan
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart. 2.3 At least one government entity has learned about Accelerator lab methods. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries. 1.1 2 new sources of data per year • Data generated by conducting a Behavioural Insights trial and using pre- and post-assessment surveys in the UN House Single-Use Plastics Free Workspace experiment • Data generated by conducting a series of talks, interviews, innovation challenge and issue mapping exercise with the Food Waste expert community and food waste challenge applicants 1.2 3 different type of data sources per year • Solutions for plastic pollution and Single-Use Plastics ban global data research • Plastic pollution footprint calculators • Press clipping on the topic of Food Waste in Bosnia and Herzegovina • Catalogue of European projects and initiatives around Food Waste (https://tool.reducefoodwaste.eu/) 1.3 20 new potential solutions per lab per year • 35 ideas, learning and experimenting opportunities identified following the thorough UNDP CO internal sensemaking process • 12 potential solutions to tackle plastic waste in Bosnia and Herzegovina identified • 26 solutions submitted on Accelerator Lab organized Food Waste Challenge in partnership with the City of Sarajevo 1.4 2 innovation methods per Action Plan • Single-Use Plastics Free Schools toolkit developed (based on Design Thinking methodology) • Single-Use Plastics Free Workspaces toolkit developed based on Behavioural Insights EAST (Easy - Attractive - Social – Timely) framework • Toolkit to develop prototypes and record learnings by the participants of Food Waste challenge developed • Use of Innovation Challenge modality in organizing Food Waste Challenge Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets. 2.1 3 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. • The Labs work was very well showcased to a broader audience with significant media presence around the Labs public launch event and through blog posts depicting the start of the Labs work in the country and learnings from the Single-use plastics experiment as the first learning cycle successfully implemented. Furthermore, the announcement of the Food waste innovation challenge was followed by the (social) media promo campaign resulting with good public outreach. The blog segment on the CO web page was “re-established” to meet the Lab’s needs for this type of reporting. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart. • The BIH Lab established successful cooperation with the City of Sarajevo through joint implementation of the Food Waste innovation challenge in Canton Sarajevo. 2.3 At least one government entity has learned about Accelerator lab methods. • The BIH Lab established successful cooperation with the City of Sarajevo through joint implementation of the Food Waste innovation challenge in Canton Sarajevo. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. • Given that the BIH Lab operated only for four months in 2019, the percentage of the actionable knowledge to ongoing CO project was lower than 50%. However, the Lab did manage to generate more than 30 ideas, learning and experimenting opportunities for the CO ongoing projects. This supported the Lab to start its integrating role among projects. Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) Result: The BiH Lab was both collectively and individually in constant contact with the network. All members are active in their role communities and seek advice and partnership with other Labs in the experimentation cycle, attend weekly calls and learn from the experience of others. 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. Result: The BiH Lab shared the Food Waste innovation challenge and the approach to decreasing single use plastics use through the network’s MS Teams channels and regular blog updates. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 2 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. Result: The BiH Lab’s work is regularly featured in CO’s social media channels but probably not as often as twice a month, due to the size of our programme and the number of news featuring on our social media channels. All key activities of the Lab are also promoted on members’ social media accounts and we support the announcements made by other Labs as well. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. Result: Our work in 2019 was featured in traditional and social media due to the high visibility of our October 2019 launch event and the Food Waste Innovation Challenge.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 5 new sources of data per year 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart 2.3 At least one government entity has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) 3.2 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries. 1.1 5 new sources of data per year • Two surveys on desirable carbon footprint offsetting options (for individuals and business entities) served at the end of carbon footprint calculation in the web app developed by the Accelerator Lab (www.tvojCO2.ba) • Business tendencies/expectations survey conducted in three occasions (April, June, October) to measure the impact of COVID-19 on MSMEs and mid-caps in Bosnia and Herzegovina, informing the Economic Pulse of Bosnia and Herzegovina web solution developed by the Accelerator Lab (https://puls.zamisli2030.ba/) • Survey to map economic response and recovery measures and identify good practices across all government levels in Bosnia and Herzegovina • General population survey conducted on desirability of using coupon platforms to support micro and small businesses during the COVID-19-related lockdown, in partnership with all coupon sites in the country • Conducting a survey on interinstitutional cooperation in Bosnia and Herzegovina during the COVID-19 pandemic, informing the specific UNDP CO project • Conducting a survey on COVID-19 impact on women in Bosnia and Herzegovina, informing the specific UNDP CO project • Digital transformation readiness assessment for local governments and cities in Bosnia and Herzegovina 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year • Combining electronic surveying and CATI method to assess MSMEs business expectations in relation to developing pandemic • Using digital solution developed as carbon footprint calculator to track opinions of individuals and business on possible offsetting options • Using catalogues of digital solution mapped by the G20, OSCE and other institutions as options for the country 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year • 15 possible solutions identified as carbon offsetting options for individuals and businesses • 11 solutions identified as digital response solutions for COVID-19 • 104 solutions proposed in the CovIDEJA2020 innovation challenge organized by the Accelerator Lab in partnership with IT industry association of Bosnia and Herzegovina • 34 solutions identified in the Zero Waste Communities innovation challenge organized by the Accelerator Lab • 5 solutions proposed in the Change Makers 2021 UNDP CO internal innovation challenge, organized with purpose to incite more cross-sectoral innovations, 3 initiatives implemented 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan • Soliciting innovative ideas and solutions to address development challenges using innovation challenge modality • Tracking the behaviour of users while using web applications to detect their opinions on different topics • Organizing a series of Future Talks, virtual events organized by the UNDP Accelerator Lab in Bosnia and Herzegovina and centred around pressing issues or inspiring development opportunities. Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 6 blogs, or other (substantial) media posts published per year. • TheLabs work was well showcased to a broader audience with significant media presence around the first national online ideathon in the country - covIDEJA2020, the first national CO2 footprint calculator - TvojCO2, the Economic pulse online data dashboard, and COVID-19 economic recovery measures platform, circularity pilots, etc. • A couple of blogs post were published depicting the learnings from the interventions listed above. • Several (social) media mini-campaign were organized to promote the above-listed interventions and digital tools and ensure wider public reach. • Extensive media coverage of the covIDEJA2020 ideathon and its winners. • Several video stories were produced to showcase the interventions results (e.g. video stories about five circular pilot companies and their transformational journey. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart. The BIH Labs interventions in 2020 had to take a hard shift to COVID-19 response to what was initially planned at the beginning of the year. In these interventions, public sector support was up to 10% as the Lab partnered more with private and civil sector, academia and international organizations. In 2020, the Lab established more than 30 formal and informal partnerships supporting almost all activities and interventions. 2.3 At least one government entity has learned about Accelerator lab methods. • The Lab continued the collaboration with the City of Sarajevo on the topic of Food Waste. • Federal Ministry for Environment and Tourism supported the organization of the first national digital ideathon, covIDEJA 2020. • The Lab also supported the CO project in integrating the innovative approaches in their activities with the different governmental counterparts. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects. • In 2020 the Lab supported all UNDP BIH sectors in implementing their activities and designing and developing new ways to continue with the project activities in COVID-19 imposed new normal and new interventions, activities, and learnings. This integrative role of the Lab resulted in up to three new projects (Medical waste management, Circular pilots, Digital Pulse) and a vast number of minor interventions related to ongoing CO projects such as Digital Transformations, SDG Bussines Pioneers, Via Dinarica, POPPs, DRR, EU for Bussines/Agri, Dialogue for the Future, Women in Elections, IT Girls, etc. Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning.
3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) Result: In 2020, the BiH Lab actively collaborated at least thrice a week with a number of colleagues from the network on COVID-19 related experimentation, shared our insights and practices through MS Teams and WhatsApp groups and conducted a number of bilateral and multilateral meetings within the network aimed at learning and scaling. 3.2 25% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. Result: The Lab shared methodology and results on a number of experimentations in 2020 with the network – we presented our collective intelligence work on COVID response and the Economic Pulse experiment during weekly calls with the network, and the results of the circular economy pilots and the CO2 calculator were featured in various channels of the network. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Network´s work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. Result: The BiH Lab’s work is regularly featured in CO’s social media channels but probably not as often as twice a month, due to the size of our programme and the number of news featuring on our social media channels. All key activities of the Lab are also promoted on members’ social media accounts and we support the announcements made by other Labs as well. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 2 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem. Result: Our COVIDEJA innovation challenge and the first FutureTalk were well received in the local development ecosystem and widely featured on different social media profiles. The establishment of the Sarajevo Food Lab was also attractive for local social media.

Output 1: UNDP Country Offices and partners will have increased capability for scanning, sensemaking and experimentation for sustainable development solutions in 60 developing countries.
1.1 5 new sources of data per year 1.2 6 different type of data sources per year 1.3 35 new potential solutions per lab per year 1.4 5 innovation methods per Action Plan.
Output 2: New sustainable development solutions will be scaled at country level as part of UNDP’s country programme and operations, national policy and/or local markets.
2.1 At least 6 blogs or other (substantial) media posts published per year. 2.2 At least 50% of our learning challenges have the public sector as counterpart 2.3 At least one government entity has adopted an accelerator lab method. 2.4 At least 50% of our learning challenges are providing actionable knowledge to ongoing CO projects.
Output 3: A core global level result will be that a global learning and scaling network is established and functioning. 3.1 The lab interacts at least once a week with another lab in the network (48 interaction per year) 3.2 5% of information shared across the network should be methodology, or sustainable development issue and opportunity related. 3.3 The Accelerator Lab Networks work is featured at least 3 times per month in Country Office Social Media channels and tag UNDP Accelerator Labs accounts. The Lab team engages at least once a month across any social media conversation related to the work of the Accelerator Lab Network, from either personal or CO account. 3.4 Connect the Accelerator Lab’s publications to local development ecosystem through social media. Identify and engage with 5 new relevant local social media profiles of the broader Development Ecosystem.
